.  It was named after its founder, James Barnes.

value: State Route 800 runs through the town north and south.  It connects to Interstate 70 six miles north of the town.
State Route 147 runs roughly east and west through the town.

As the village is only home to between four and five-thousand inhabitants, there is noting in the way of public transportation, so plan on using your car or, even better, walking.

value: directions=Located on State Route 800 north of Barnesville, between the village and Interstate 70

content=A 4,5000 acre ranch built on reclaimed strip mine.  Home of up to 1,500 registered Dutch BueLingo, Texas Longhorn, and African Watusi cattle.  Tour covers history of horned cattle in Ohio, Johnny Appleseed, Hopalong Cassidy, Ohio governor Wilson Shannon, and Hanging Judge Isaac Parker.  See cattle being trailed and branded on this working cattle ranch.
hours=Th-Su, last full weekend in September
price=Free for most of the festival, $1 or less for craft displays

content=Local festival that began in 1964 and now attracts more than 100,000 people annually.  Pumpkin growers compete to grow the heaviest pumpkin each year, crowned the King Pumpkin.  (Current record was set in 2007 and weighed in at 1,289 1/2 pounds.)  Other attractions at the festival include an Antique & classic car show, crafts, new and antique farm machinery, live music on multiple stages, and contests for hog calling, tall tales, and tobacco spitting.  The event reaches its peak attendance on Saturday for the Giant Pumpkin Parade.

content=Fully restored, twenty-six room Romanesque style mansion.  Sights include carved woodwork, moldings, mantels and doors, as well as 22k gold decorations, decorative locks, hinges and gas and electric lighting fixtures.  Houses one of the largest collections of original clothing from the 1890's in Ohio.  Annual Christmas tour runs from Thanksgiving to Christmas.
content=Three floors of tools, furniture, glass china, quilts, pottery including Roseville and Weller, primitives, and more.

content=Grandma's Country Store brings a bit of Amish Country to Western Belmont County.  They carry a unique gathering of antique and country treasures and many primitive finds.  Grandma's offers many handmade and refurbished items including benches, shelves and cupboards.  You will find many wonderful gifts that your friends and family will be delighted to receive.  The store is filled with pictures, scented candles, primitive dolls, crocks, crocheted doilies, crows, sheep, and home decorations.  We invite you to bring your family and friends to Grandma's Country Store.  You can check us out on our website, grandmascountrystoreonline.com
content=Family owned, small town restaurant featuring home cooked meals at very reasonable prices.  Hosts murder mysteries, comedy shows, and live bluegrass and other music.
directions=Follow State Route 800 south out of town for about 5 miles
content=Local drive-in eatery featuring homemade ice cream.

content=(Opening the first weekend in December 2010)Brings a part of Amish Country to Barnesville with a gathering of antique/country treasures and many one-of-a kind pieces. Outside Barnesville, on the east side of town.

Bob's Pizza And Sub Stop
Delicious food at reasonable prices. Alcohol and cigarettes can be purchased as well. They've got Pizza, subs, wings, onion rings, pepperoni rolls, calzones, and more!

value: price=Single $70 weekdays, $75 weekends, Double $90 weekdays, $95 weekends

: Barnesville's hometown radio station, a member of the AVC Communications Inc. family.  Broadcasts Cleveland Indian baseball games and local high school football, basketball, and baseball for the Barnesville Shamrocks and Monroe Central Seminoles.  175 East Main Street, 740-425-9268.

: Weekly local newspaper covering western Belmont County, in operation for over 140 years.  It is the oldest active, continuously operated business in the village.  166 East Main Street, 740-425-1912.

: 125 Electrified campsites and featuring hot showers, picnic tables, and firerings.  Pets allowed in designated areas.  Swim, fish, boat, or hunt (in designated areas).  65330 Barkcamp Road, 740-484-4064

: Fish or boat on 12-acre Park Lake.  Watch baseball or softball on one of three lit ball fields, one housing a covered grandstand.  Lit horseshoe pit, basketball courts, tennis courts and valleyball court.  Two walking trails that wind around Park Lake.  Also home to the villages 4 July fireworks display.
